summary.text: Whether HTTP compression is enabled. By default, it's

The level of zlib compression to apply to responses. A higher level will result in better compression but will take longer to complete. 
A lower level will result in less compression but will be much faster. The default value is

How much memory should be allocated to the internal compression state. It's an integer in the range of 1 (minimum level) and 9 (maximum level). 
The default value is

The minimum response body size that compression is applied on. Its value can be the number of bytes or any string accepted by the 
[bytes](https://www.npmjs.com/package/bytes) module. The default value is
Essential configurations related to the Medusa backend, such as database and CORS configurations.
The Medusa backend’s API Routes are protected by Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS). So, only allowed URLs or URLs matching a specified pattern can send requests to the backend’s API Routes.

is a string used to specify the accepted URLs or patterns for store API Routes. It can either be one accepted origin, or a comma-separated list of accepted origins. 

Every origin in that list must either be:

1. A URL. For example,

. The URL must not end with a backslash;
2. Or a regular expression pattern that can match more than one origin. For example,
. The regex pattern that the backend tests for is

content.text: Some example values of common use cases:

```bash
# Allow different ports locally starting with 800
STORE_CORS=/http://localhost:800\d+$/

# Allow any origin ending with vercel.app. For example, storefront.vercel.app
STORE_CORS=/vercel\.app$/

# Allow all HTTP requests
STORE_CORS=/http://.+/
```
If you’re adding the value directly within
, make sure to add an extra escaping
for every backslash in the pattern. For example:

```bash
# Allow different ports locally starting with 700
ADMIN_CORS=/http://localhost:700\d+$/

# Allow any origin ending with vercel.app. For example, admin.vercel.app
```

summary.text:
A random string used to create cookie tokens. Although this configuration option is not required, it’s highly recommended to set it for better security.

In a development environment, if this option is not set, the default secret is

However, in production, if this configuration is not set, an error is thrown and 
the backend crashes.

A random string used to create authentication tokens. Although this configuration option is not required, it’s highly recommended to set it for better security.

In a development environment, if this option is not set the default secret is

However, in production, if this configuration is not set an error, an
error is thrown and the backend crashes.
The name of the database to connect to. If specified in

, then it’s not required to include it.

Make sure to create the PostgreSQL database before using it. You can check how to create a database in 
[PostgreSQL's documentation](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-createdatabase.html).
The connection URL of the database. The format of the connection URL for PostgreSQL is:
: (required) your PostgreSQL username. If not specified, the system's username is used by default. The database user that you use must have create privileges. If you're using the

superuser, then it should have these privileges by default. Otherwise, make sure to grant your user create privileges. You can learn how to do that in [PostgreSQL's documentation](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/ddl-priv.html).
-
: an optional password for the user. When provided, make sure to put
: (required) your PostgreSQL host. When run locally, it should be
: an optional port that the PostgreSQL server is listening on. By default, it's
. When provided, make sure to put

: (required) the name of the database.

You can learn more about the connection URL format in [PostgreSQL’s documentation](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/libpq-connect.html).

This configuration specifies what database messages to log. Its value can be one of the following:

- (default) A boolean value that indicates whether any messages should be logged.
- The string value

that indicates all types of messages should be logged.
- An array of log-level strings to indicate which type of messages to show in the logs. The strings can be

. Refer to [Typeorm’s documentation](https://typeorm.io/logging#logging-options) for more details on what each of these values means.

If this configuration isn't set, its default value is
, meaning no database messages are logged.
An object that includes additional configurations to pass to the database connection. You can pass any configuration. One defined configuration to pass is

which enables support for TLS/SSL connections.

This is useful for production databases, which can be supported by setting the

. 
During development, it’s recommended not to pass this option.
Whether to fail connection if the server certificate is verified against the list of supplied CAs and the hostname and no match is found.

Used to specify the URL to connect to Redis. This is only used for scheduled jobs. If you omit this configuration, scheduled jobs won't work.

:::note

You must first have Redis installed. You can refer to [Redis's installation guide](https://redis.io/docs/getting-started/installation/).

:::

unless you’ve made any changes to the Redis configuration during installation.

.

for the list of available options.
An object of options to pass to [express-session](https://www.npmjs.com/package/express-session).

Configure HTTP compression from the application layer. If you have access to the HTTP server, the recommended approach would be to enable it there. 
However, some platforms don't offer access to the HTTP layer and in those cases, this is a good alternative.

If you enable HTTP compression and you want to disable it for specific API Routes, you can pass in the request header
The configurations for your Medusa backend are in
located in the root of your Medusa project. The configurations include database, modules, and plugin configurations, among other configurations.

exports an object having the following properties:

-

: (required): An object that holds general configurations related to the Medusa backend, such as database or CORS configurations.
-

: An array of plugin configurations that defines what plugins are installed and optionally specifies each of their configurations.
-

: An object that defines what modules are installed and optionally specifies each of their configurations.
-

: An object that enables or disables features guarded by a feature flag.

For example:

```js title="medusa-config.js"
module.exports = {
  projectConfig,
  plugins,
  modules,
  featureFlags,
}
```

---

## Environment Variables

It's highly recommended to store the values of configurations in environment variables, then reference them within

.

During development, you can set your environment variables in the

file at the root of your Medusa backend project. In production, 
setting the environment variables depends on the hosting provider.

---
This property holds essential configurations related to the Medusa backend, such as database and CORS configurations.

On your Medusa backend, you can use [Plugins](https://docs.medusajs.com/development/plugins/overview) to add custom features or integrate third-party services. 
For example, installing a plugin to use Stripe as a payment processor.

Aside from installing the plugin with NPM, you need to pass the plugin you installed into the

.

The items in the array can either be:

- A string, which is the name of the plugin to add. You can pass a plugin as a string if it doesn’t require any configurations.
- An object having the following properties:
    -
: An object that includes the plugin’s options. These options vary for each plugin, and you should refer to the plugin’s documentation for available options.

In Medusa, commerce and core logic are modularized to allow developers to extend or replace certain [modules](https://docs.medusajs.com/development/modules/overview) 
with custom implementations.

Aside from installing the module with NPM, you must add it to the exported object in

: a string indicating the name of the module.
    2.

: an object indicating the options to pass to the module. These options vary for each module, and you should refer to the module’s documentation for details on them.
    3.
: a string indicating whether the module shares the dependency container with the Medusa core. Its value can either be

. Refer to the [Modules documentation](https://docs.medusajs.com/development/modules/create#module-scope) for more details.
    4.

: a string indicating a unique alias to register the module under. Other modules can’t use the same alias.
    5.
: a boolean value indicating whether this module is the main registered module. This is useful when an alias is used.

Some features in the Medusa backend are guarded by a feature flag. This ensures constant shipping of new features while maintaining the engine’s stability.

You can specify whether a feature should or shouldn’t be used in your backend by enabling its feature flag. Feature flags can be enabled through either environment 
variables or through this configuration exported in

.

If you want to use the environment variables method, learn more about it in the [Feature Flags documentation](https://docs.medusajs.com/development/feature-flags/toggle#method-one-using-environment-variables).

The

configuration is an object. Its properties are the names of the feature flags. Each property’s value is a boolean indicating whether the feature flag is enabled.

You can find available feature flags and their key name [here](https://github.com/medusajs/medusa/tree/master/packages/medusa/src/loaders/feature-flags).

content.text:
:::note

After enabling a feature flag, make sure to [run migrations](https://docs.medusajs.com/development/entities/migrations/overview#migrate-command) as it may require making changes to the database.

:::
